critical_instructions.item: Analyze ONLY the final image provided for analysis. NEVER analyze any example images provided earlier.
Absence of war map content is a valid outcome. Do not force identification if no military cartographic content is present.
Be exhaustive - extract EVERYTHING visible on the map.
When uncertain about symbology, describe what you see and provide possible interpretations.
Distinguish between what is explicitly shown and what you are inferring.

war_map_definition.item: A war or battle map is a cartographic representation of military operations, positions, or terrain for military purposes.
War maps typically show troop positions, movements, fortifications, and tactically significant terrain.
They may depict a single engagement, a campaign, or strategic overview of a theater of operations.
War maps use specialized symbology to represent military units, movements, and installations.
They often include temporal elements showing the progression of military operations.

symbol_category.name: unit_symbols
symbol_category.item: Rectangles often represent military units, with internal symbols indicating type.
X symbols typically indicate infantry; diagonal lines may indicate cavalry.
Dots or circles often represent artillery positions.
Size indicators (I, II, III, X, XX, XXX) show unit echelon from company to army group.
NATO symbology uses standardized shapes: rectangle (unit), X (infantry), oval (armor).

symbol_category.name: movement_symbols
symbol_category.item: Solid arrows typically indicate main attacks or advances.
Dashed arrows often show planned or secondary movements.
Curved arrows may indicate flanking or encirclement.
Arrow thickness may indicate force strength.
Multiple arrow heads may show sequential movements.

symbol_category.name: defensive_symbols
symbol_category.item: Zigzag lines often represent trenches or defensive lines.
Crossed lines may indicate obstacles or fortified zones.
Star shapes often represent forts or strongpoints.
Hatched areas may indicate minefields or restricted zones.

symbol_category.name: terrain_symbols
symbol_category.item: Contour lines show elevation; closer lines mean steeper terrain.
Green often indicates vegetation or forests.
Brown may show elevation or unpaved roads.
Black lines typically show roads, railways, or boundaries.

color_conventions.convention: Red often represents enemy forces or danger areas.
Blue frequently indicates friendly forces (in Western maps).
Black is commonly used for text, roads, and boundaries.
Green typically shows vegetation or sometimes friendly forces.
Yellow may indicate caution areas or specific unit types.
Historical maps may use different conventions - analyze the legend.

not_war_maps.item: Tourist or road maps without military content are NOT war maps.
Political maps showing only boundaries are NOT war maps.
Topographic maps without military annotations are NOT war maps.
City plans without military context are NOT war maps.
Fantasy or fictional battle maps should be noted as such but can still be analyzed.

historical_context_clues.item: Uniform styles and equipment depicted can indicate era.
Unit designations and organization suggest specific armies and periods.
Place names and boundaries help identify the conflict.
Cartographic style and printing technique indicate approximate age.
Language used provides clues about origin and perspective.
